defined "the sub-imperial style."
"In the sub-imperial style, power is
exercised not by individuals but by big

organizations," he said.

bureaucratic momentum created a wall
of resistance to any interference from

the President."

lines of the dormitory snack bar
and the cold plastic city of the
Levering cafeteria.
Located about five blocks east

offers the student a chance to
walk past the famous marble
stoops of Baltimore to get
something to eat at any time of
day.
Starting at the south end of
the street, the first possibility to

not so sumptUous cuisine is the
infamous White Tavern, open 24
hours a day. The sign outside

Security waste
The vast wasting of money for security at the East
Baltimore Medical Institutions illustrates again the
hypocrisy of an administration that is constantly curtailing
vital University functions in the name of fiscal stability.
The University is spending over $500,000, according to
one estimate, for a Pinkerton guard service which is widely
criticized by East Baltimore personnel and the guards
themselves as ineffective. The guards are poorly trained,
usually elderly and ill-equipped to handle thefts and
attacks in this high-crime area. The University carelessness
with funds is similar to the $440,000 deficit piled up last
year by mismanagement of nine University-owned
businesses in the East Baltimore area.
Prior to Lincoln Gordon's ouster last year,
administration waste and over-expansion were a constant
source of criticism. But now that Dr. Eisenhower has
returned, the complaints have quieted down, although
financial irresponsibility apparently remains.

SC disaster
The initial SC move to cut ties with the administration
until it gave students policy-making power was a promising
one, but it has now degenerated into a foolish catastrophe
for all members of the Hopkins community. Instead of
following up this drastic measure by coming up with a
strong, concrete governance proposal, it has failed
altogether in formulating a plan and appears headed
towards a timid compromise motion that aims only at
keeping student representatives off committees until that
feeble advisory group, the Arts and Sciences Advisory
Council, agrees to make governance the sole topic of
discussion. But even more damaging is the stubborn
insistence of the SC in ending student input and funding
for some of the most valuable committees and activities.
Despite strong student opposition, the Council wants to
take undergraduates off the Presidential Selection, Student
Union and Student Senate committees— all of which are at
least trying to be worthwhile. In addition, the SC's
adamant desire to cut off funds from the Eisenhower
Symposium and the Kennedy-King Lectureships strikes
hardest at students, who benefit most from these two
exciting series on an otherwise dull campus. To end
administration connections to get real power requires a
careful cultivation of student support and shrewd tactical
judgment. All this is absent in the Council's childish and
heavy-handed approach.

care," referring to the sacred
attitude many athlete
broadcasters have towards their
former profession.
Distinctive

sounded like he was speaking
into a mocrophone. The words
came out in short phrases, with
the same pauses and flourishes
and garnishes of verbiage that

head perches slightly ahead of
his body, giving him the look of
a vulture about to pick clean the

Merlin Olsen, Roman Gabriel, and Howard Cosell
bones of an errant quarterback.

value of this institution that
attracts so much attention to
him. "Sports is not important
except as an escape, which of
course is necessary in the
swiftness of today's world." But
discussing the reserve clause, he
points out, "If baseball did
expire, the war in Vietnam
would not be shortened, no
ghettos would be leveled.
America wouldn't stop."
He sees his job as approaching
sports with the attitude of a
serious, objective and skeptical
journalist, and he reacts harshly
to some of the criticism he
receives. "What do I do? Drop
my Phi Beta Kappa key down
the sewer and become a $130 a
week hack sports writer?"
Merlin Olson and Roman
Gabriel approached and
exchanged verbal jabs with
Cosell, the sportscaster of course

said, stating that they recognize
his knowledge of football. Part
of that knowledge included his
observation that "Gabriel is a

lousy quarterback. Utterly
predictable." It is these personal
encounters that seem to give

meet exceptional people. They
are like all people, but they
endure the pressure of
performing in the public arena."

He himself calls Muhammad

sixties where the most important
things happened out the arena."

Avery Brundage, the reserve
clause. He described the move of
the Senators as "disgraceful and
cheap."
"The owners try to have it
both ways. They're a free
enterprise when they jump from
town to town. Then they go
before Congress and say they're
something special and need to be
exempt from anti-trust
measures."

"If they want to be, in effect,
a public utility, then we need a
federal agency of sports and a
federal sports commissioner,"

wife and family, "and nothing
else." He looks forward only to

some time to spend with them,

the prejudices and divisions of
southern America and middle
America and bring them to the
fore."
He says that the youth are
"our hope, where it's at," due to
their "awareness, sentiment,
sense of values, inquisitive
nature and an educational
foundation my generation and
ones previous didn't enjoy." He
claims to enjoy most his weekly

speaking engagements on college
campuses.

also seems to enjoy his Monday

problem in broadcasting is not

afternoon, when games are
played in Westminster Abbey,

my bag."

Security waste
The vast wasting of money for security at the East
Baltimore Medical Institutions illustrates again the
hypocrisy of an administration that is constantly curtailing
vital University functions in the name of fiscal stability.
The University is spending over $500,000, according to
one estimate, for a Pinkerton guard service which is widely
criticized by East Baltimore personnel and the guards
themselves as ineffective. The guards are poorly trained,
usually elderly and ill-equipped to handle thefts and
attacks in this high-crime area. The University carelessness
with funds is similar to the $440,000 deficit piled up last
year by mismanagement of nine University-owned
businesses in the East Baltimore area.
Prior to Lincoln Gordon's ouster last year,
administration waste and over-expansion were a constant
source of criticism. But now that Dr. Eisenhower has
returned, the complaints have quieted down, although
financial irresponsibility apparently remains.

SC disaster
The initial SC move to cut ties with the administration
until it gave students policy-making power was a promising
one, but it has now degenerated into a foolish catastrophe
for all members of the Hopkins community. Instead of
following up this drastic measure by coming up with a
strong, concrete governance proposal, it has failed

Sunday Bloody Sunday, a
movie about a man and a woman
who are in love with the same

The three main characters, all
Londoners, are: Daniel Hirsch, a
homosexual doctor in his forties,
played by Peter Finch; Alex
Greville, a thirty-ish

Bob is the keystone of the
film, because he needs to be a
believable character; bisexual

normal experience, and you are
shocked to find how oddly
paired both of his relationships
are. Penelope Gilliatt talked
about how she envisioned him in
an interview with Vogue:
"I wanted him to be another
species of animal, someone from
another planet, like a Martian, a
mutant. He doesn't know about
being cruel, he has no sense of
cause and effect." Her
screenplay, along with John
Schlesinger's direction,
accomplishes just that. Bob is
cool, he doesn't care about how
he affects Daniel or Alex, and he
hops back and forth between
their beds with gay abandon. I-Te
avoids any kind of pressure, he
does exactly as he pleases, and
he has a difficult time
understanding why other
people's lives could be in the
least confused.
The doctor, Daniel Hirsch, is
the strongest role in the film. He
is homosexual, but he is not
grotesque or pathetic. He is
lonely, but he is resigned to it.
He is, vaguely content with the
half a loaf he gets from Bob, and
his sexual tendencies are not
particularly influential on the
rest of his life. He is an
intelligent and compassionate
doctor; able to dispense stoicism
to his patients because he is able

times it becomes very difficult
for him not plead with Bob for
favors. He has planned a
vacation in Italy for the two of
them, but when Bob tells him he
might go to America, Dr. Hirsch
tells him he has to make his own
choice. He obviously longs for
him to stay, and go to Italy with
him, but he restrains himself.
This scene is very packed with
emotion, but it is a pity that it is
wasted on Bob, who couldn't
recognize jealousy if it kicked
him in the face.
It is intentionally unclear, it
seems, whether the Doctor is
content with his relationship
with Bob. Finch's acting is so
polished and he stays so much in
character that it is difficult to
elucidate his desires. You can't
tell whether he is simply the
proverbial concerned doctor of
just another frustrated queer.
This is either a tribute to Peter
Finch or to Penelope Gilliatt,
but not to both.
Dissatisfied

"The only protection against

present system promotes.
